citation.article-title: Halogeometricum rufum sp. nov., a halophilic archaeon from a marine solar saltern, and emended description of the genus Halogeometricum
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Emended description of the genus Halogeometricum Montalvo-Rodríguez et al. 1998
Cells are pleomorphic (short and long rods, squares, triangles, ovals and irregular cocci) under optimal growth conditions and stain Gram-negative.
Colonies are pink–red due to the presence of bacterioruberin carotenoids.
Sugars are metabolized, in some cases with formation of acids.
Cells contain PG and PGP-Me, but phosphatidylglycerol sulfate is absent.
In some species, the major glycolipid is GLb (an unsulfated glycolipid), and S-DGD-1 may be present as a minor component.
In other species, the major glycolipid is chromatographically identical to S-DGD-1 and DGD-1 may be present as a minor component.
The DNA G+C content is between 59.1 and 64.9 mol%.
The type species is Halogeometricum borinquense.
